reviewText:
Having almost reached the 1200 mark in hours played, I have decided to step away for awhile and attend to real life stuff.

Would I recommend this game?

Absolutely!

I spent a whopping $5.00 and poured hours upon hours into this game (poor Gf!) hehe.

In my experience, there has been nothing that is remotely comparable to the visceral feel of the combat that Chivalry provides. The voice acting, the grunts when you swing your weapon, the bloodcurdling screams and gurgling of your enemy as he dies after you have dispatched him. And most of all -- how challenging the game was to get even semi-competent at my loadouts of choice.

If you are a gamer that likes to immersive themselves with dedication in trying to master a very difficult game -- this is for you. If you can leave your ego at the door and just play for the experience --while constantly studying the whys and what nots  --> you will be rewarded by seeing your battle prowess increase. But, IMO, dont expect an exponential curve of progress. This game is a slow burn" of countless defeats coupled with many small victories along the way.

*notable moments:

The moment that you live through your first 3 v 1 or 1 v "many" and press "x9" as you walk away from the slain.
The moment you learn how to get kills with the catapult or ballista and your opponents rage at you in chat.
The moment you participate in a king v king duel and win.
The moment you decapitate that "scum" archer
date: dishing out your knightly justice.\nThe moment you feint and kill your opponent
recommended: only for him to cravenly throw up a votekick that fails.\nThe moment where the art of "dragging" finally clicks.\nThe moment where playing with your chiv friends is an awesome
hoursPlayed:
fun pasttime -- where the chat is good natured trash talking.

So many moments and many more not covered.

Find your playstyle

reviewText:
Chivalry Review

Gameplay
In Chivalry: Medieval Warfare you can play as Vanguard, Knight, Archer and Man-At-Arms.
Vanguard is more for long range combat, becouse he oftes use long weapons.
Knight is mainly for doing alot of damage.
Man-At-Arms use short weapons and are very fast, so his attack speed is better but he dont do as much damage and he needs to get close to the enemy.
Archers are long ranged, they use bows and crossbows, but they also have a dagger.
You generate health automaticly when you have full stamina.

As a Newbie
As a newbie there are servers that are limited up to maybe level 10. This makes it alot easier to get into the game, and really understand/ learn it.

Mods?
Chivalry do have modded servers. For example one mod gives you a lasersword insead of the normal weapons, it's basicly called Lasor Sword Mod.
Another one makes you bigger the more kills you get without dying, but when you die you go back to normal, it's called  Giant Slayers.
The last one im going to tell you about is the Black Knight mod. In Black Knight you can lose a arm, a leg, both arms even your head without dying (I think you die after 10 or 15 seconds if you lose your head....), and it's really fun.
There are maps you can download too.

Summery
It's a great game, I would say pick it up when it's on sale, I bought it on summer sale 2015, my friend recomended it.
Just so you know there i ingame purchases, but it's only skins and nothing you really need.
I don't like that they have ingame purchases, they are already charging pretty much when it's not on sale.
But I love that they have modded servers.

I hope you found this helpful, if you did could you please give it a thumbs up so I can that what Im doing is correct, if you would like me to change something in my review please write a comment, :D

reviewText:
I had previously written a positive review with strong caveats but am changing it to negative.  At this point I feel that the bugs and the developers' ignoring of said bugs (especially after the release of the DLC) have too much of a negative impact on the game to enjoy anymore.

The game from a design standpoint is fantastic.  They made the best melee combat system I've seen in a game and there's a good variety of maps and game modes to play around with.  The style of the game with lots of gratuitous severing of limbs and decapitations and the ridiculous warcries gives it a nice over-the-top feel that make it a lot of fun.

Unfortunately there are many bugs, some of which completely destroy any concept of class and weapon balance, that have existed since release.  The developers flat out refuse to acknowledge that these bugs even exist, much less fix them.  They have shown themselves to be completely clueless about weapon balance as well, often buffing the stronger weapons in patches and nerfing the weaker ones.  From what I understand the situation has only gotten worse since the release of the DLC.  Every server is pretty much guaranteed to have several people exploiting these bugs and ruining it for everybody else.

So while I did have a lot of fun with the game when it was new, mostly before the bugs were widely exploited, there's no way I can recommend it now.
voteText: 22 of 34 people (65%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A decent multiplayer action game (no singleplayer!)

Chivalry is similar to Mount & Blade and War of the Roses games. Like WotR, Chivalry is much more fast-paced than M&B. Unlike both M&B and WotR, Chivalry has no mounted combat at all, although it's not a huge drawback, it's still something relevant. Maps in Chivalry are small and the game offers a lot of game modes: deathmatches, capture the flag, king of the hill and many more. During the game the player chooses one of four classes - an archer or light/medium/heavy infrantry. They play quite differently - their speed is different and weaponry differs as well. However, the game suffers from terrible hitboxes - some weapons hit the enemy while they seem to be still far away from him, while other seemingly go through enemies harmlessly. In addition, there seems to be some kind of autoaim when playing archers, it seems very easy to just headshot a lot (or I am very good at it, which I doubt a lot as I'm not a good FPS player). There is a huge amount of graphical bugs or half-baked meshes and textures. Overall, the game is fun and I recommend getting it, albeit after some time it gets a bit stale. I definitely enjoy it more than War of the Roses and vanilla M&B, but cRPG servers in M&B Warband still remain my favourite swordplay action game.

+ fun!
+ interesting game modes
+ decent combat

- terrible hitboxes
- no horsies
- a lot of bugs

+- tiny maps
+- very arcade and quick

reviewText:
I regret buying this game.
I bought Chivalry Medieval Warfare for the sake of getting my jollies off of the fact that I really do love anything medieval that tries to go for some sort of realism. However I'm sad to say that this game did not deliver on my expectations at all.

First thing here is the issue with teamkilling. Teamkilling in this game is barely punished, all you get after hurting your team is more seconds on the respawn counter. That's not a good punishment at all, and that's only because team killing happens every 15 seconds of the game. You would think that your teammates would know what teams they're on but no. There's so many things in the game that gives you no excuse on being hostile to friendies, and the two big ones are your team colors and uniforms. Now if this game took the Red Orchestra 2 approach and made it so there was a system that automatically votekicked you unless you were forgiven by teammates I wouldn't mind this at all. However instead the only votekicking there is seems to be ignored by everyone.

Another issue with this game is how ♥♥♥♥ing horrible combat is. Animations don't even have to be done and I'm already beheaded. Why would you let your game have something like that. There's also a mechanic in the game where if you swing your body in the same direction as the attack it'll go faster and slower if you swing a different way. Now something  like this would be very cool, too bad that this mechanic is ruined by the fact this actually breaks the game since you could make your mouse have a seizure while mashing buttons and just recieve free kills. And oh, if you don't have ping under 80-90 good luck even landing a hit. It's worse than the Morrowind combat if you were to swing a sword while being trained to use axes.

And finally there's the fact this game takes a stupid practice of DLC that I never condone, the cosmetic DLC. Street Fighter IV, Dead or Alive, and that Evolve game that recently came out. Customization is actually pretty nice in this game since you're allowed to have your personal units look like what you want but man I hope you want to shell out $2 if you really like a specific helmet.

Overall I can't say you should ever waste your money on this game. I wasted $8 since there was a sale going on, but please just avoid this game. From what I heard even if you git gud" at it you only are gonna get into a community that's L4D2 terrible.

Just pick up Mount and Blade Warband instead."

reviewText:
When it comes to medieval games, this is definitely one to have in your library. It goes on a cheap sale price so be sure to keep an eye out for it!

This game literally throws you into action and provides you with more than a simple swing the mouse and chop someone. The game has an awesome fighting engine. It's accurate and very rewarding while playing. What sets this one apart from other hack and slash's is the way you have to be facing the enemy to block or attack (and even dodge). On top of that, there are variances in the swings you can engage in. Rolling the mouse wheel backwards allows for a heavy overhead swing, while rolling it forwards provides a front poking motion extending your reach. Left button allows for a swing left to right while right mouse button is to block attacks. There are other swing variances that you should look into as I've set one of my extra mouse buttons as a side swing from right to left. Swing types matter as it could be the difference between hitting an opponent and accidentally hitting your own team-mate (which can be a regular occurrence given the right ignorance). Alternative attacks and different classes mix the game up and can really halt your strategy after receiving an arrow or axe to the head. The best game mode would be Team Objective (raid the castle) as being able to use some of the in game props like throwing torches or using a giant mounted crossbow can be just as fun as the modern day shooters.

Objectives also change as you may be trying to free prisoners one game, another game you may be trying to slay the King's family. Just make sure you don't get a dimwit using the catapult or you and the enemy will go flying. Other modes include team death match, which is two teams going straight for one another, free for all, dual mode (where people go one on one), king of the hill, last team standing and capture the flag. Different classes are also available. There is man at arms, who is the fastest but least armor. Vanguard, who when he sprints, raises his sword over his head and can do a lunge jump attack unlike any other class. Knight, who is the slowest but has the most armor and does the most damage. Last but not least, the archer, who can still fight with a dagger but is better off shooting arrows. Swords can also be swapped in for maces and axes. There are other variances available as well for your other weapons such as throwing axes or mini-explosive fire bombs that burn enemies.

Graphics and sounds are phenomenal. Everything seems to be given a realistic touch and levels take places from beautiful rolling hills to being on top of a volcano. If you get hit, you will see blood. Sounds of metal clanging together or being blocked can be heard throughout the game. When running, players are given the option of pressing C" to make their character yell. It can get intimidating when 15 players are running after a few guys all yelling at the top of their lungs.

Really fun to play for a while or simply drop in for a quick game. It's learning curve at first is a little difficult but after realizing how the game works get ready for flying vanguard sword attacks.

8.3/10


For future Chiv games : adding horses or some sort of vehicle system may be appreciated for a Chiv 2 or some sort of update. There is a nice big open map available

reviewText:
I don't usually write reviews, but I do like this game and hope it could be better.

Pros:
This game is fun.  It would be worth paying money for if they fix the problems.

Cons:
There are a lot of bugs that indicate a lack of polish
* I can't set my screen resolution for fullscreen to anything but my native desktop resolution.  Workaround is to set game to windowed mode with a set resolution via steam launch options then set to fullscreen after login.  There is a change resolution option in the game, but it doesn't have any options but my desktop res.
* When attpempting to join a game that is full, a chunk of code error shows up rather than a message saying the game is full.  Not a problem, but seems like something that would be trivial to fix.
* Game objectives that show up on the map sometimes have game error text rather than actual names
* There is apparently a known bug on arena team matches where you sometimes don't spawn.  Based on other posts it has been around a long time and is quite common.
* Players in team matches can apparently have skins/colors that override the team color, so the only way to tell what team they are on is to mouse over them and see if the dot is red.  This is rediculous.
* Performance on a lot of maps is terrible, mainly because they make them large with tons of detail.  We don't really care how pretty the game looks, we'd rather it not chop.
* Archer is quite frustrating to play.  Quite often shots go right through people without hitting them.
* Block seems to be able to block attacks even from behind if attacking with a slash, and from multiple opponents.
* There is no cost to being blocked.  If two people keep blocking/attacking each other, it will continue endlessly, pretty much regardless of weapon speed (dagger might be the only exception.)  I've heard it's supposed to attack faster after you block (riposte) but if it's there it's too miniscule to matter.  Think Assassin's Creed swordfighting without having a counter attack. This also applies to blocking multiple enemies simultainously.

reviewText:
A real slap in the face to the orriginal Age of Chivalry community.

This game takes everything the orriginal game did right and does it wrong.
Movement is on par with being in a straight jacket there is absolutely no flexability
whatsoever. You can not customize swings as you can barely turn at all when attacking .
This leads to linear boring uncreative combat.

If you think lighting fast reactions times will help you think again. Combat is slower than watching grass grow. You can comfortably go and make yourself a cup of tea  come back and still have time to parry.

I've heard of simplyfying games for the masses but this is rediculous.

The controls are also needlessly silly needing a dedicated button to switch for a particular weapon , fast weapon scrolling is not an option. There are also dedicated buttons for each single opposite direction attack instead of 1 key that would revert the attack angle.

Another thing worth mentioning is its disregard for it's historic roots. The iconic Mason dragon is replaced by yes.. a bird..  and mason knights now look like muslim warriors .

If your into skilled gameplay and lightning fast reactions stay clear of this game and check out Age Of Chivalry the best FPM of all time.

reviewText: I'm done with this game seriously.\nAt first it is fun while playing on the 0-15 servers. After that it's a freaking ballerina-fest that everyone makes pirouettes and abuse hitboxes. Unblockable overheads that pass through tower shields, reaches that won't even reach you and somehow the rank 50s have some sort of super speeds that kill you even if you block. Oh and not to mention teams formed of 40+ rank steamrolling everything they see, and rank 5 smurfs which kill newbies which are the greatest scum on earth.\nIf you have friends and buy this during sale play this for a while. reviewText:
Chivalry: Medieval warfare is a first person combat comedy simulator game. This competitive game centers around a team or an individual who must complete a certain goal. These certain goals range from clustering up 32 players in a tiny arena match and forcing them to kill each other, pillaging villages, killing the kings relatives and many more, all so players can rank up and get better weapons.

Now to get on to what really happens when you play Chivalry. While playing this game, you will encounter many spaztic youths that are fully capable of decapitating your head in a single blow with a knife - apparently crouching down and staring up at the sky while preforming an overhand attack is powerful enough to chop a fully armoured mans head off. There are many other realistic ways you can be killed, such as recieving a punch that causes your head to explode, getting slammed into the ground by a ballista bolt or getting killed by that third arrow hitting your head after the first two lodged in your skull didn't kill you before. Higher leveled players may sheath their mauls or sledgehammers and beckon you to fight with the ol' fisty cuffs. Of they'll make sure you don't land a punch on them by ducking and weaving like a crazy Mike Tyson and you'll probably recieve a punch that causes your head to detatch and fly miles off the map. Obviously these tides can be turned around, and you may be the Captain of the ship - a winner.

Anyway, great game and it can get competitive with friends and randoms alike. Easy to learn although difficult to actually master, this game will keep you entertained for a while especially when you learn all of the combat exploits/tricks etc.

reviewText:
I woke up to see this game in the steam store, I quickly downloaded it to see what the hype was all about, as soon as it was downloaded I was about to click the play button when all of a sudden I got a knock at the door, I was startled at first so I jumped up to check the peep hole, and whoever it was on the other side had their finger over it so I got suspicious an grabbed my gun, I yelled who's there!?" No reply so I asked once more... I got the same silence so after contemplating for the next several minutes I decided to open the door.

My initial reaction was to shoot....BANG...BANG...BANG... I stood in shock as I found out it was my american stepbrother.
I was in tears
recommended: all three of my rounds had entered his heart...but then I looked down he had his laptop in his hands...with this exact game running. He had come over to see if I had bought and downloaded it because this game is so awesome. So I played chivalry on his laptop for many hours

reviewText:
Dear god, this game is so good.
Where to start?
STORY: Agatha Knights hate the other dudes. They fight. GG.
GRAPHICS: Hilarious with all of the dismemberment and gore. Looks quite beautiful if a bit clunky at times with camera movement.
GAMEPLAY: Amazing. A first person medieval combat game with 4 classes: Archer, ranged guy. Man at Arms, speedy little mouse with solid weapons and excellent movement. Vanguard: Heavy character with weapons that have high reach. Knight: Shield+Sword or Battleaxe. GG.
There are weapon unlocks, but you have decent enough weapons to start with. You can block, parry, fake, stab, overhead, and slash. Simple yet amazing with the different classes and weapons.

♥♥♥♥ the wierd review, but the game. It feels great. It looks great. It IS great.

Final Verdict: Must-buy for anyone.

reviewText:
This is a clusterf*** of bugs and imbalance. I've played this for months, got about 400 hours in, and it's not getting any better.
I promise you this game will never be balanced or fixed, because the developers are pretty obviously incompetent, and the game's mechanics fundamentally flawed. It's fun at first with the carnage and all, but you'll smell the BS pretty soon, and eventually see how incredibly unbalanced and bug-ridden this game is.

I can just hope that another company is going to make a professional, balanced and working game like this.
You know, a developer that doesn't declare a game-breaking exploit (dragging) a feature instead of fixing it, or makes DLC while in BETA. DLC that of course is similarily unbalanced and bug-ridden, of course.
I know I'm never going to touch any Torn Banner games ever again, that's for sure, and I advise you to not encourage this kind of bullsh*t and spare you the rage.
This game could have been awesome, but it never will be. Shame.

reviewText:
This game is a ton of fun. It doesnt necessarily look the best (Unreal 3 engine I believe), but it more than makes up for it with solid gameplay, ballsy attitude, and well populated servers (32 player matches). It's multi player only, although you can set up private servers and populate with bots if you prefer. Matches are your typical Deathmatch, Objectives (which are basically one team defending and the other attacking with objectives as you go along such as burning down or crashing gates, smashing towers, and so on on route to eventually trying to kill the King), Free For All (everybody vs everybody), etc..., but they are all quite fun. I've played through four different maps so far. I'm not sure how many more there are, but it's a little consequence. The gameplay is more important than the locations with this game.

The learning curve can be steep depending on the type of warrior you select as well as their loadout, (which is initially limited, but unlocks more stuff as you keep getting experience), but it is also pretty easy to get into the flow of the game. You WILL die a lot, and often in hilarious ways, such as getting set on fire just before having your head and an arm hacked off. You can also shout battlecries to your hearts content, lol.

You do get penalized for hitting your own teammates, which takes the form of longer respawn times, and if you are a repeat offender, everybody on your team gets to vote on whether or not to kick you. You can also switch sides if you like, mid game, and in fact, the game will sometimes rebalance and shift you automatically to even out the teams.  Speaking of respawns, while you are waiting, you basically are the ghost of your now dead warrior and can float around and/or above the battlefields checking out the battles while you wait.

All told, the game is a ton of fun to play, and I think it is pretty hilarious as well, with the graphic deaths, copious battle cries, and people running around like madmen.

Initially, I thought this was about 8/10, but the more I play, the more I lean closer to a full 10/10.

reviewText:
BUY IT.
Theres always room for improvement in this game and it is very skill based. When you start out you may complain about cheap tactics and heresy but when you get good you'll understand why you die everytime and improve and eventually you'll kick butt like me mmhmm
-Jul 20, 2013 @ 4:32pm


EDIT: 1300 hours in. Never gonna stop!
This game's core combat is beautiful. There are a few flaws in balance, and annoying tactics that some use, but at its core, the combat is purely skill based. The only way you'll ever beat the best is to be the best, and the only way you ever lose if because you screwed up. This game has made me obsess with training to become the best, to beat the best, the prove that I am the best. I have never been engrossed in anything like this before. Truly, the best game I have ever played.

There are bugs, however, but they aren't so overwhelming that they drown out the rest of the game.

If you are looking for skill based melee combat, this is the best game to get.

reviewText:
Chivalry Medieval Warfare is a multi-player only game made by a company which was later bought by Thorn banner studios. The concept is simple, It’s a team based, hack and slash game with game-mode’s such as free-for-all, last-team-standing or duel mode, where you can pick up two kingdoms, either Agatha and Mason. Just remember to play the tutorial, before going online.

I highly recommend this game if you are wanting to put more than 50 hours into it, you’ll start slow, since there are skilled players who know how the game mechanics work, but that said, you’ll eventually learn and outplay them!
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Awesome game, 9.9/10.

Love the wimpy archer voice, makes me wanna squeeze their cute chubby faces with a longsword.

I rated 9.9/10 and left that 0.1/10 because there was no campaign. Imagine being in the world of Agatha, and starting rhe campaign in the Crusades, after being shipped from the training course, and seeing your side being completely smashed, developing the story. From there, you are given the opportunity to choose which side you shall bare: The Mason Order of the Agatha Knights.

Going on through the campaign, your choices change the outcome of battles, missions and so does your participation to these fights. Eventually the campaign ends in the side you helped the most, by either fighting as best you can and choosing the best for your side when you up the ranks, or if you decide to betray your side with foul deeds.

Also, I'd like to see in this campaign why, exactly, the Agatha Vanguard is so ♥♥♥♥ing batshit insane XD

reviewText:
Medieval WarfareAfter a very fun 500 hours of gameplay I have decided to make a review of this game. First of all, this game is super fun once you get used to getting smacked around by a bunch of 360 spinning vanguards with bodies of jelly. But besides that this game is amazing. It is quite amusing chopping off peoples limbs and yelling Help". This game definitely takes some getting used to. Hell 500 hours in and I'm still level 29 (probably because I'm just bad).

Pros:
- Graphics are pretty well done
- The game mechanics are well balanced
- Very fun community
- Good selection of weapons (psst thrusting dagger/shield combo OP)
- Constant updates patching bugs

Cons:
- All the level 50+ that are just amazing at this game.
- After a good while the maps get a bit repetative (thank you map mods)
- Hit boxes sometimes get a bit janky

Overall this game is well made and fun. I have made multiple friends playing this game and it continues. +1 to you Torn Banner.

Deadliest WarriorThe expansion is (in my opinion) a better version of MW. There are many different classes with diversity. Each class has a wide variety of weapons and items to use. I feel that this expansion was saddly abondoned though. I haven't seen any updates fixing the many bugs. Also some weapons are very overpowered (Spartan Dory I'm looking at you).

Pros:
- Graphics and mechanics are good.
- A big leap from MW
- Much bigger variety of classes
- Most of the classes have their own little special ability.

Cons:
- Very buggy
- No balance in a few of the weapons.
- Once again the level 50+ that spin around with their swords like they're trying to perform some sacred dance of the earth god (wait what? exactly)

And here shall end my review of Chivalry. I would recommend this game for a friend. It is definitely worth its price. I can already tell that this game will consume another good portion of my life.

Overall score 87/100"

reviewText:
I really want to give this game a good review, but in the current state it's in, I just can't. It's a great game, but with how many countless bugs there are, I'm not sure this is worth full price. Some of the bugs that come to mind are the HUD shrinking whenever you change any option, vignette always re-enabling itself, weapons displaying the wrong stats, viewmodels and your camera breaking during many actions including reloading and interacting with the environment,  the crossbow randomly re-sighting after loading bolts, and the team balance. Dear God, the teambalance.
It can be 8 v 10, and it balances you to 7 v 11. If you try to change back to make it 8 v 10, it won't let you, and will instead do nothing, or make you a Vanguard. It can be 1 v 3, and if you keep winning, seemingly to spite you, another person joins and makes it 1 v 4. The team balance in this game does not exist, because it is just a malevolent spirit who wishes players from one team to another off of no basis.
This isn't a new game, either. It's been out a long time, and has many, many microtransaction cosmetics in it, so there is no reason for so many glitches.

There's also New Player" servers which have most of the players and only allow 'low' ranks in
date: but the rank limit is high enough that the top skill level players are already in it
recommended: but if you happen to pass the rank you have to scrounge for a server with decent connection
hoursPlayed: the right gametype

reviewText:
Outlandishly entertaining // Recommended for the competitive and the violent
+ Blissfully short load times
+ Player base is still active and freshly populated
+ Environments and set designs are extremely creative and well laid out; makes for matches made even more interesting by environmental obstacles and means of escape
+ Engine seems to be smooth-running and well-optimized
+ Game is absolutely flush with customization; is predominately geared towards aesthetics, though alternate weapons can also be unlocked/purchased
+ Plethora of innovative and extremely entertaining game-modes; keeps the game interesting by keeping these in constant circulation on most servers
+ Mod support and Steam integration make for an even greater variety of environments and other factors
+ Combat mechanics are smooth and responsive; may feel a bit clunky initially, but this quickly melts away as the player acclimates to the play-style
+ Controls are intuitive
+ Netting kills in this game is immensely, alarmingly satisfying
+ Graphics are nothing special, but they have aged well, and generally look slightly above average
+ Voice-overs are intentionally comical; helps keep the game relatively light-hearted and entertaining
+ Objectives often include fun and challenging mechanics, such as operating siege equpment and trying to push carts to objectives in the midst of a hellish melee

- Team killing is a pervasive issue throughout
- Glitches abound, although few are game-breaking, and they can often be funny enough to add to the experience
- There is a bit of an initial learning curve, though it is quickly overcome
- Absolutely rife with microtransactions, many of which feel inordinately expensive; these are entirely optional, however, and frugality does not detract from the game's experience

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements, and I also have a budding YouTube Channel for those interested. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
About me. I was following this game closely since start at 2012.
Have bought 4pack just to support devs.

Lets summarize why this title did not succeed. For those interested in gamedev.
Key to success is movement towards main goal.
Two ways to fail: (1) you do not do what needs to be done, but (2) wasting on useless things.
Instead of digging into their main features - close range combat with all possible details, like (ask your nearest game dev about these):

* Damage models
* Range accounting

In case of melee fight, there should be more improvements about
* Accurate simulation of dynamics - speed and angular moments of contacting bodies.

Finally if everything is cool, something should be done about
* Advanced melee fighting controls.

Instead of this developers screwed with laser-guided archers and other useless unnesessary bs that finally ended this title.

I think Dishonored2 could possibly take close range combat into their forge" to cast something out."

reviewText:
Well, if you like brutal games with dismemberment and clumsy, poorly made and humorous melee combat this is the game for you.

Why do I not recommend?

At a glance I enjoyed this game. It was fun, truely, but then I started seeing the flaws in it. Big holes that couldnt be patched out.

One: Aim Botters. They have them for this game, believe me. But Draconis
date: arent you being biased and just QQing about being killed?" No. Go look in my library and youll see I have over 300+ FPS games
recommended: most of which have hundreds if not thousands of hours in them. I know what aim bots look like
hoursPlayed: and how to test them to see if Im right or not. This isnt the kind of game you pre-fire on either
voteText: so there arent any legit excuses for "blind shotting" people across a map in the head consistantly.\n\nTwo: Block/Parry/Dodge. You have a stamina meter for really no reason other than to say that you get two attacks and maybe three blocks before you cant do anything more. This is up there with Battlefield sprint. A few seconds and its good night for you. Its not a fast combat game any longer. Thisisnt so much the problem as the game's tutorial tells you that you can get a counterblow after a block. That is an outright LIE. You block
helpfulPercent: then they can block directly afterward.\n\nThree: Speed Hacks. Yes they have them
votesHelpful: along with
votesTotal: as far as I can tell
votesFunny: Stamina Hacks so that people can consistantly and progressively attack without stopping. If you ahve played more than five minutes
commentsCount: you will understand there is a visible differance between a constant
column16: instant attack seven times with a pike stab vs you playing with a pike and getting three stabs before your stamina is gone between attacks and blocks.\n\nFour: No VAC or any risk of cheaters even being repremanded. I think they siad they had a cheat protection
column17:
but people were very quick to see others behind walls and stop at doorways before they came around to get a free hit.

Five: A whiny ♥♥♥♥♥ass community that made reading chat a huge head ache for me. There is a way to turn off chat I think but I really didnt want to bother. I just stopped playing after hearing some debate about racist words that no one gave a ♥♥♥♥ about.

Six: Everyone is experienced but you. This means access to better
column18: faster weapons and more effective equipment. This can be comparable to COD where you are rank 1 and they are rank 40. Sure you have weapons that can kill
column19: just not as well as theirs. And I do mean EVERYONE has this sort of rank. Out of ten servers

as I was 30 ranks lower than the lowest rank in every server.

reviewText:
Really astonishing experience, if you like to feel like a medieval knight. This is the game I was looking for, a medieval FPS, quite well balanced (althrough you can use some tricks, which will let other just wonder how you could kill them and why didn't their block work). But once you understand how the game works, you will become the true king.

If you see it on sale, go for it.
The Deadliest warrior, on the other hand .... meh.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: This is simply put the best sword fighting game created. It's easy to learn but extremely extremely hard to master. Everything about this game is satisfying. Every limb and head you crush or slash feels extremely realistic. This game is so much fun and has good mod support. Ounce you get to the higher levels they're are a lot of people that look like they are on cocaine with their swings and they will own you. I wish there was a way people could play with others that don't do this. I also don't like how the developers charge you for character skins that players create. There are so many workshop mods but the developers hardly ever add any into the game. This is extremely dissapointing thinking about how many fun game modes and new weapons and armors could be added into the game. All in all this is a great game to pick up and play for a quick match or two, or for prolonged play sessions.

reviewText:
Chivalry: Medieval Warfare...

This game tests your reaction speed and quick thinking. With a large amount of weapons to choose from this game gives a nice variety to different situations. A leveling system that also rewards you with new available weapons and armor/color. A solid amount of maps to play and servers to play those maps in. Full controller support(be sure to max your sensitivity, trust me).

I have clocked in over 500 hours into the game because I cannot get enough of the killing, the winning and the vast amount of fun this medieval combat presents me.

Those moments when you are outnumbered and surrounded and you unleash your instinctive ability to fight for your life, kick that person, duck the first swing, turn around with a swing, chop head off, lunge towards unsuspecting fighter with s stab to the chest, turn to final opponent, block, overhead swing, overhead again... Such sweet moments. I personally enjoy using the Knight with Maul to smash my enemies' heavy armor in.

There are 4 different classes to choose from: Man at Arms, Knight, Vanguard and the Archer.


I love this game as much as I love people, so much that I just want to chop them all up.

Truly, a game worth playing over and over again. 10/10, 5/5 * * * * *

reviewText:
Solid, first (if you use third person you are a dead-to-me scrub) person melee (archers too ok) combat game. The combat mechanics themselves are pretty straight foward but there's plenty of nuance (spasmic mouse movements to adjust path of attack and thus pass your opponent's defenses) to it.

I really enjoy it and most of the community is pretty respectful. Good game.

Always mash C while sprinting.

reviewText:
^^ You see that play time on record? Yeah, admittedly grossly embarassing: like a dirty drug habit you just can't shake- but alas a brutally honest true-grit testamate to the replayability and entertainment that this game provides.

If you're a decently quick visual learner and a sword swingin' advocate that loves online mayhem, then you need look no further. This game has everything you're looking for, even at it's standard price.

So what are you waiting for?! The 2014 Summer Steam Sale is on- and you're practically stealing from the devs!
See you on the battlefield! ;)

reviewText:
There's a lot that can be said about Chivalry: Medieval Warfare, but it all boils down to this:

RRRAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAH!

Basically, you run, you shout, you chop people's limbs off in the most satisfying way imaginable, and you get good, and then you chop even more limbs off plus smash some heads in with a giant hammer (that stuff never gets old). Do some objectives, come hither, oooo look: a rainbow!, run some more, duel, duel on TO servers, get scolded for duelling on TO servers, go on a duel server, get rekt, go back to TO and behave! Rinse and repeat. Fun, fun, fun!

It's like being inside The Kingdom of Heaven (the film, not the actual place) with all its visceral beauty and gore. It will get your heart racing and you'll feel every slash, every bash and every stab. Decent headphones are a must - there is no sound more awe-inspiring than that of someone's helmet, skull and brains being mushed into a sticky pulp with one drop of a maul. It's just beautiful!

Stick around and you'll meet some of the nicest people around (at least EU-side, but I do have friends in the States too). Community-driven events and antics happen all the time and you can count on veteran players helpin you out with tactics, optimisation and anything really. Sure, there are a few bell-ends too, but every game has a few, nothing to be concerned about. Talk to me if you need anything and I'm sure 99% of players over 50 lvl will say the same.

In terms of graphics - little bit outdated, but it's UE3 so there's no surprise. Sound design is superb, rivalled only by that of Alien: Isolation and I'm not saying it lightly. Playability? Let my 1100hrs of gameplay speak for themselves (at the time of writing this review).

In closing: don't be a scrub, join in on the fun!

P.S. DEATH TO ARCHERS!

reviewText:
This game is currently where most of my hours are invested in.
Unless you have friends that play this game, I wouldn't highly recommend it but it is still fun nonetheless.

I bought this game close to its release date, back then the community was casual, players were still adjusting to the combat system, class system and the plethora of weapons they had at their disposal. It was all fun and games, either dying to a dagger or having your face caved in by a maul. All players were deciding their play style. It was and still is fun, however one the main issues is the constant lack of good fixes from the developers, I'm not talking about the animation glitches such as reversal overheads but the hud, miscellaneous game changes as well as the map exploits. I've only came back a few months ago.

There are numerous times that the hud has become glitchy, when you're playing with friends and you see that green marker, you know exactly what I'm talking about. This has been a bug for quite sometime and these 'fixes' are not really doing anything. The gritty melee death camera is a notable example, having your character in first person and stay in first person when you die is gruesome especially when you see your head getting sliced apart from you body, it was all for immersion or when the in game voice chat has been removed because people were abusing it? Simply add the mute option to everyone and they themselves can pick who they want to personally mute,I remember when the King character would rally his men and lead the charge in the final minute of the match, it was exhilarating. Map exploits are still present, i.e spawn camping, spawn glitching as well as unorthodox map areas which were meant to be inaccessible such as the Arena.

Now how does the game currently fare? Excluding all the bugs or lack of proper fixes?
- The community
If you're playing for the first time, you need to know that the majority of the current chivalry community consists of very high level players most of which have over hundreds or thousands of hours of game time, you will get crushed by them, over and over, it is inevitable. Some even exploit the newcomers for the gain to finally reach level 50 for that golden helmet. Many will kick you for friendly fire, abuse your lack of knowledge about the game and overall they can be infuriating at times.Now you must understand that not all veteran players are like this. Many see that it's great that the game gets revitalised by newcomers, even with the occasional annoyance of friendly fire. This is where you see the duelyard servers, these servers contain a community that is more than willing to help you with the game, as well as giving you opportunities to have sessions with veteran players and useful tips they can provide, just ask. It will take time, that is for sure to be able to withstand pro players or even hold off 20 seconds of their slaughter but the more you do hold them off, that is an achievement you can be proud of as you invest more time into the game.

-The combat system
We now come to the combat system, we all had our taste of metal, enjoyable is it not? To visibly see the impact your weapon made to the enemy. This is what splits Chivalry from the rest of medieval games, the immersion. This has since been broken by the introduction of fighting techniques such as the reversals,drags and accelerations. But you must think, if the game resorted to just feints and left clicks it wouldn't be fun would it. To be able to pull those moves off is a testament to how skills players have become, whiffing such moves or having people block said moves is a death sentence. This is the skillcap of the game, despite the animation glitches when pulling such moves. As a new player, of course you aren't able to pull these off right away and you'll be dying to them a lot, but when you do pull at least one of them off, it is satisfying. Plain. Satisfaction.

-Tips when starting out
Use the tutorial system, I cannot stress this enough, even if you can't stand to hear the instructor's voice over and over. It will teach you that there is more to combat than simply LMB, learn to block at the right moments, use different attacks, find a class that is worthy of your play style and see what weapons you want to specialise in.
If you do team kill, please apologise in chat, it may mean the difference between you staying on the server with a positive outlook or serve as a major thorn in the side. Team kills happen a lot, it's not uncommon but not saying anything afterwards will really tick the recipient off as though it was intentional.
Don't give your hopes up, we were all new players once,it's hard trying to combat someone that you have no chance of winning in a 1v1 but coordinate, such as in TO, no one lives long enough to contribute if they attack on their own, learn to use stabs in group fights, act as support and if all else fails let the veterans take the brunt of the fighting and see if you exploit other areas.The optimisation is still poor, the developers need to get up and start dealing with these issues now rather than release more and more cosmetics.

In the end, you will find people who will destroy you, you will find people who will help you, you will need to take time in order to even 3v1 the absolute veterans. This is the process of any combat game. Is it a bit of a mess? Sure, but for only $5, it's a great mess.

reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to lop someone's head off? Have you ever wanted to taste the glory of the battlefield? If you salivate at the prospect of a competitive, online, medieval-style war game with siege warfare and bloodcurdling screams,  then BUY THIS GAME!!!  I'd give it a 8.5/10, but incredibly addicting!  Most players you will notice have 1k+ hours.

I will give you some deets if you are on the fence/generally interested but not convinced. Slightly lengthy but compiled well.

--------
<PRO'S>
--------

COMBAT:
-The combat system is more robust than anything else out there.
-Ability to drag (slow down) and accelerate (speed up) attacks by moving your mouse certain ways.
-Overheads, stabs, and horizontal attacks are all in melee possibility along with kicks and shield bashes.
-Spacing, positioning, situational awareness, teamwork, dodging projectiles, siege warfare, timing, and skill are pivotal.
-Ability to parry attacks, block with a shield, riposte attacks, and dodge (if Men At Arms)
-Your attacks seem to have real weight and consequences to missing as opposed to something like mount & blade or war of the roses.

GAME MODES:
Each game mode benefits a growing player's skills as each will get you good at certain aspects of the game.  There are also a few different mods out there. Some for competitive play (mercs), and some for fun (black knight, giantslayer, laserswords, horde)
-Team Deathmatch-----(Good at building teamwork and straight-to-the-point kill tactics)
-Free For All------------(Better for learning situational awareness and being in the ♥♥♥♥")
-Capture the Flag-------(Also good at building teamwork and battle tactics)
-King of the Hill---------(Helps build team engagement prowess and situational awareness)
-Duel Yards-------------(Good at learning 1vs1 tactics and the nicities of fighting an opponent/parrying)
-Team Objective-------(the longest and most fun/immersive IMHO. Promotes teamwork towards a common goal.)

VOICE ACTING:
Now this is something you wouldn't think would be a huge part of the game
date: but it adds a lot of depth. Especially when used in the right context by players. each class for both Agatha and Mason have about 20 different voice commands
recommended: each with 5 varieties of what is said for that "command"
hoursPlayed:
along with a battlecry.  This brings a new level of immersion to the battlefield

CLASS SELECTION:
Fairly simple
voteText: but effective class selection.  Four classes
helpfulPercent: each balanced in their own respect with a different playstyle for each.  Tons of weapon selection with a basic enough principle for each. Different Damage
votesHelpful: Reach
votesTotal: Speed
votesFunny: and preferred attack for max damage. (For examples spears have better stab attacks while axes have better overheads.)\n-Knight    (most health and armor
commentsCount: heavy hitting
column16: slower weapons and run speed)\n-Vanguard    (Moderate health and armor
column17: very long weapons
column18: cannot combo with spears-types
column19: charge attack)\n-Men At Arms    (Low health and armor
column20: very fast attack/movement
column21: can use firepots
column22: has dodge)\n-Archer    (piddly health and armor
column23: 1shot by almost all knight weapons
column24: medium speed
column25:
excel at killing from afar)

------------
<NEUTRAL>
------------

ADVANCED TACTICS:
The game has a lot of fine nuances. This actually fleshes out the combat system even more for competitive purposes
column26:
adding a lot of depth. Tactics that have been adapted over the game's lifetime are utilized by a lot of high-tier players. These include:
-The fabled reverse overhead
-Head Feints
-Feinting
-Rubberbanding
-Target switching
-Combo-feint-to-parry

The reason this is neutral is because on one hand
column27: I don't think a lot of these tactics were intended
column28: but rather were discovered throughout the community to be effective means of utilizing the game mechanics. On the other hand
column29: they really start to take away from the game's immersive nature. In rare situations
column31:
these can seem like exploits.

---------
<CON'S>
---------

NEW PLAYERS:
This game has a fairly unforgiving learning curve. I suggest any new player play the tutorial before playing online against other players
column32:
and to experiment with all of the classes while playing until you find the class that best suits your playstyle.  This will ensure 1.) that you end up playing the class you were fated to and 2.) that you at least understand from firsthand experience what the other classes are capable of when you are fighting them.

GLITCHES & DESYNC:
-Every now and again you will get caught in an odd place
column36: an odd crevice. In this situation you'll have to press F10 to kill yourself or someone can kick you out of it if you're lucky.\n\n-Desync will occur sometimes. This basically means your game client and the server don't agree on what is going on
column37: despite what may appear to be happening on your screen.  Sometimes you will experience a stab that seemed way too freaking fast
column38: an animation that didn't seem to quite play
column39: or someone rubberbanding around somehow.  It doesn't happen enough where it's overwhelmingly noticeable. In fairness
column40: these issues can be expected in any online game
column41: but are only particularly frustrating in chivalry because time
column43:
and visuals are such an important element in the complex combat system.


All in all
column44: if you are even slightly interested in the aforementioned aspects of a medieval deathfestival
column45: you cannot pass this game up if it 50% off or more.\n\nIt offers the most emmersive medieval melee combat experience out there.  It has the capacity to be both hilarious as all hell and competative to a stressful point (if you pursue competitive). There have been games where I have gone ten+ lives in a row without killing a soul.  Then the next life
column47: I will go on a 7 man killing spree involving a legitimate 4v1 situation and lop a few heads
column48: and it gets me rock hard.  These are the moments I live for in chivalry."

reviewText:
I have less than 200 hours, so take my review with a grain of salt.
Unless you're interested in playing competitively, and learning every abstract technique in the book, just play it with friends. The swordplay is really crazy and fun, but the community mostly consists of veterans with thousands of hours. This makes the learning curve almost entirely vertical, as you'll never have the chance to test your mettle against people of similar skill. You will most likely die to veterans without fully understanding why, again and again. If you can overlook the skill disparity between veterans and newcomers, there is a really enjoyable and deceptively complex experience to be had.

Most veterans are beginner friendly, willing to teach anyone who is willing to learn. In fact, there is even a pinned thread in the Steam forums where players can offer/request coaching. That being said, there are a handful of high-level players who perpetrate a toxic environment by insulting anyone of a lower skill level than themselves. These people are best ignored, as they often get stomped by the more approachable veterans.

If you're looking for a Medieval swordfighting game with a high skill ceiling, and you don't care about immersion-breaking bugs
date:
buy at full price. It's absolutely worth every single penny.

If you're looking for an immersive online Medieval swordfighting experience, you might be disappointed. Wait until the next Free to Play Weekend, and try it before you buy.

If you're thinking about buying the Medieval Warfare and Deadliest Warrior bundle, DON'T.
They abandoned DW, and it's heavily unpolished in comparison to MW. Just buy the base game (MW), and spend that extra money on a weapon skin or something.

reviewText: Overall, a very good game for the money. Whilst it's riddled with imbalance issues and has a steep learning curve you can never fully master, it achieves what it sets out to do. The sound effects are second only to the likes of battlefield’s and the graphics, while not the most amazing, are smooth and pleasing enough to carry the game through. This game is not for the feint hearted or those easily frustrated, prepare for counter strike style rounds and re-spawning.\nThe highlights of the game aside from the unique combat really are the objective game types. These prove to give hours upon hours of satisfaction and something to play for. The ranking system for Medieval Warfare is probably one of the worst/laziest I’ve seen to date so you will not have much else incentive except of course unlocking a variety of weapons that becomes frustrating in itself. If you’re looking for a better rank system; I recommend getting deadliest warrior, however, as yet there are no objective game types sadly.\nMy recommendation would be to buy this game. It well worth the full price, but don’t expect it to be perfect. In many ways the game still plays like the BETA but I believe that in time the developers will polish the game and combine elements of the DLC & original game for a better product & a more completive game.

reviewText:
Things I learnt about Medieval Warfare:

- Shields didnt exist unless held infront of face

- Tip cuts can penetrate steel plate to the bone

- Edge alignment Is a complete fallacy

- Instead of weapons everyone used rods coated with lava

- Medieval soldiers used roller skates

- No one could hold thier weapon to their face for longer than three seconds

- Back in the day people could block greatswords, waraxes and mauls with thier kitchen knives

- A man at arms was actually a cookie cutter light unit despite popular belief

- It was possible to fight with full plate armor, a two handed heavy maul, a tower shield and a broadsword

- A brandistock was far heavier than a spear simply because it had a few more metal bits

- Hitting someone on the foot did as much harm to clobbering someone round the head

10/10 would pass history class again!

reviewText:
Chivalry is a purely multiplayer based game with no quests or story to follow.

During my extensive time playing this game I have had many of laughs at the ridiculousness in the game as well as many rage quits and fits of anger due to the much respected skill of other players. The developers at Torn Banner wanted to create a game where you could feel like you were a character in an epic war movie such as The Last Samurai, Braveheart, 300, etc. They have done a very good job at meeting that goal and that is one of the reasons I keep coming back to this game. If you want to have an epic battle you can play team objective, or if you would like to fight someone with honour there is duel mode, or if you just want to get away from the main game there are many mods such as lightsabers, giant slayers, horde mode, and we cant forget the amazing expansion of deadliest warrior. Before I talk about the game mechanics and issues with the game i'd like to first say why I enjoyed it so much.

Well lets start from the beggining. You buy the game (perhaps in an online sale?) and start it up. When you get to the main menu you have a free choice of joining a quick match with no idea what the game even looks like or by playing the tutorial (Which I highly recommend before playing online). During the tutorial you meet some pretty funny AI instructors who will introduce you to the basics of the game as well as a couple of cutscenes describing the story behind the game. Afterwards you may enlist online :). Now you are ready to join your first match. I know what you're thinking, What if I join a game and I get destroyed by higher level players?". Well unlike some multiplayer games Chivalry has there own low level servers for new players
date: of course you are able to play in public servers with people of all levels (Level doesnt always doesnt determine skill either ;). When you first play you will definatley have a great time! You will fight other players thinking you are a noble knight on a mission from god while you cut your enemies down in front of everyones very eyes. However when you start to get familiar with the game and start to understand the etiquette and honour this is where the game changes in a good way.\n\nOnce you have fought in enough battles and collected the heads of all your enemies at this point you should understand the etiquette and moral code of the game. At this point in the game things become less serious and much more hilarious (as stated in the intro). I saw massive swords and axes being swung everywhere and heads flying
recommended: not that funny right? Well the thing that makes this game so great is the dialogue. Each class has there own unique dialogue ranging from tactical commands to clever insults and taunts (Thats a pretty big sword! You compensating for something? - Agathian Archer Insult). Everytime I play I come across players who will crush your skull with the massive maul and then start bursting out laughing or taking your arm off with a small dagger and apologizing using the dialogue (Walk it off - Mason Knight). These small things are what make the game much more enjoyable and fun to play.\n\nNow that i've told you a bit about the game i'd like to say somethig about the combat system (finally). The combat system in chivalry is by far the one of the most realistic and interesting of any game ever made. Now the swordplay is not the same as it is in real life and to be honest im glad it isn't. I have studied swordplay and fencing and if those same techniques were incorporated into this game it would be tremendously boring and unfair to new players. The damage is very realistic and the amount of damage taken is determined by your class and weapon. For example a heavy knight weildng a morningstar vs an archer weildng a small dagger
hoursPlayed: the knight would deliver much more damage and take very little. BUT Just because he has more armour and is more powerful does not mean he can win. This leads me to another great part of the game which is balance. Lets look at the knight and archer example/ The knight has more armour
voteText: bigger weapons
helpfulPercent: and looks cooler
votesHelpful: so he should win right? well this is where balance comes in to play. The knight being stronger is much slower and the archer could simply dodge his attacks and land several attacks to gravely injure the knight or kill him as long as he doesnt get hit. After many updates and tweaks the combat system is legendary with so many different skills to use fights are unpredictable and never become boring. For new players they aspire to learn these skills to bring them into battle against there foes (under the trainign section in the main menu there are many useful videos highlighting all of the major skills that can be used which can be practiced in game).\n\nThe game is very fun (humour
votesTotal: sword-play/legendary combat system
votesFunny: fights are always fun
commentsCount: makes you feel like a bad a**) however the only negative thing is the chat box which can either have really kind players who will roleplay or help you out and make the game more fun or just people who get angry and inuslt eachother becase they are having a bad day and are getting killed a lot (but that is something that the players decide and is not the developers fault).\n\nThe final verdict for this game is great combat

I rate this game 8/10 for its amazing combat system and excellent multiplayer as well as its replayability. The game lacks a story and many rpg elements but the game was clearly intended as a multiplayer hack and slash. I reccomend this game to anyone looking for a good laugh and fun times with friends and other players.\n\n"

reviewText:
This is the first review, maybe i'll write another one..

First of all you can see that producers are like they put great effort into this game. Huge disk space, high detailed graphics and great sounds etc. Now lets see what we have;

+ Firts point is the type of game. Nowadays people are looking for medieval themed games. And if you are one of them, you can think about this game.

+ Graphics and contents are enough to satisfy gamers

+ Sounds are realy good. Unlike in warband, here you can feel your sword is touching to the enemy by its sound..

+ A lot of servers, players, contents... etc.



What about negative points;

- You need realy high disc space

- Graphics are not simplified, so you cannot play if you don't have really good computer

-  Gameplay is not very well. After playing ''Warband'' i was expecting more professional combat system.

* No direction for your hit, you hit from above and directly with your sword by some other buttons(mouse wheel). And by left mouse button u hit only one direction.
*Blocking is also only one animated move, like u hit right mouse button and it is done. No direction.. Only thing is timing.. You can not hold and wait in blocking position.
* Actually if we go deeply we can write pages. But what i mean is realy poor combat system. You cannot see your weapon's reach point like in warband. By ''see'' I mean cannot feel like in warband u can.

Actually after speeking much about ''Warband'' if we compare them, what makes ''Warband'' number one is NOT the high quality of graphics or huge contents, it is the uniqe GAME MECHANİCS like combat sysytem.. Looks like producers spent lots of money but without a perfect combat system it is not different than other thousands of games.

Finally if you ask to me ''Would you buy this game?'', ''No, I wouldnt buy it. Because even if you like the game, it is not like some special games you can play for thousands of hours.''

Best wishes..

reviewText: Possibly the most vile community you will run into in gaming. Ping divas who will complain over a ping of 80 and try to get you kicked, MLG types who rehearse the game mechanics like it's some form of martial arts so they can essentially break the game to achieve rediculous kills, people who team up together in free for all mode, resigned acceptance of spawn camping/killing, clans that will group up and votekick people for no reason other than they wanted room for their buddies... Oh, and if someone tries to tell you hackers or cheaters don't exist, they're lying out of their bloody, loose ♥♥♥♥. They exist and you'll see them from time to time running around at light speed, at a crouch no less.\n\nIt's fun as ♥♥♥♥ and once you play it, you'll find other melee games less entertaining. It's just a shame about the people who play it. Expect to get TKed repeatedly for little reason other than the other player is bored, and you can expect the majority of the server to laugh over it as it isn't happening to them. They will in fact vote no if you attempt to remove the TKer, and it seems to be a running joke to vote-kick the person who is being TKed, not the person commiting the foul.

reviewText:
I'm not sure what to say about this game. It's hilarious, and gives you many many hours of entertainment and what seems like a deep and intricate combat system. However, on the one hand, once you play it for a while, you realize how horribly, horribly buggy and easy it is to abuse the combat system. Once you discover how to slow down your attacks as a Vanguard, it's almost impossible for 70% of all players to defeat you.

The game has been out for over two years. It quickly got a lot of hype and attention from big YouTubers, but despite the massive cash-in the devs got they're evidently pretty ♥♥♥♥♥ at their job. The peasants are all identical, the kick animation is clunky and the kick mechanic itself is often downright broken. It's remarkable that Torn Banner got the combat system quite rightly addictive and still not polish their game. There are still places you can clip through, get stuck; maps can break and have had the same glitches since they were introduced. Third person is literally allowed, for some inexplicable reason, granting players objective advantage over others, making this the ultimate way to play - which is a glaring problem, to say the least, when the game is advertised as a FIRST PERSON slasher.

All this total nonsense leads me to believe that the devs really have no ♥♥♥♥ing idea what they're doing. Do they even play their own game, realizing the problems that exist? It's not even debatable that third person is the best way to play. It doesn't matter if you like it or not, if you play in third person and master it then you WILL be better than someone on that same level playing in first person.

The devs just got lucky with a solid combat formula. I'm sad to admit I've nearly spent 300 hours on the game and nearly every match there is a bug or a glitch or a balance problem that ruins it. It's been two years since the game got out of beta. I don't ♥♥♥♥ing understand how they can add more maps and fail to add unique voice commands to those maps, as was included in every vanilla map.

What the hell kind of budget do these people operate with anyway. The instance there comes along a game that is the same but is actually focused on first person I will switch, and I will also uninstall this crap. I cringe seeing it on my games list.


For a slight bit of perspective on how broken this game is at its core, here is a video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c4SzkQ2qbB4
#slasherwhen

There is a list of reasons for my thumbs down below. All you need to know if you're looking to buy is this:

-This game is not for casual players OR new players. If you did not own this game a year or two ago, don't buy it now. You will be destroyed. You will lose. You will be angry. Save yourself the frustration.-




Let me start off by saying I have a great and many hours on this game. I started playing more than a year ago, when things were a lot more fun. As time went on, the enjoyment started to sink away. I beat a good part of the learning curve and began to shine more. I would have recommended this game, and did. I brought friends to play with. Sadly, in the end, key things broke my loyalty.

1: Community. The community of this game will make you hate all of humanity. They're (not all, but many) childish and insulting. Totally unhelpful. You will run into that guy" that kicks you over and over again on your own team to goad you into attacking him so he can votekick you for team damage.

date: more of it seems to break. Be it your weapon unlocks
hoursPlayed: or the whole screen going black while you play- Torn Banner is all out of free passes in my book to get this process right.\n\n3: Hacking. There are two types of people that will tell you this doesn't happen. 1 is the guy that defends this game and thinks you're just a noob. 2 is the hacker. I knew hackers in this game

reviewText: This game is solely multi-player based. There are only 4 classes to play and a wide variety of weapons to choose from. My only gripes with this game is when you die in team matches, you only get 1 life until everybody on eihter team dies. This is the only way to respawn, otherwise you will be in specteter mode. There is also a few bugs here and there but nothing that will effect gameplay. With dedicated servers and enough people to play I recommend this game. I probably give this game a 7.5/10.

reviewText: Honestly, its a great game. If you pick this up on sale you most likely wont regret it. I certainly got my money's worth out of it. Be warned though, the game is escpecially difficult to newcomers. This game requires actual skill and knowledge of game mechanics. You will mostly play this for fun at higher levels and not for ranking up. Ranks don't really mean anything in Chivalry, it really is just skill that matters. For instance a level 25 (low) can have the same weapons as a level 50 (high) and still win in a fight. So being high ranked does't inherently make you overpowered, instead its skill, luck, and lag that wins fights.\n\nIf you do pick this up, you will be hopelessly crushed by higher levels at first, but keep trying and you will learn and get better. While I give this game a thumbs up, you start to see the many flaws this game has when you play for as long as I did, and it may discourage you as it has me to stop playing altogether, but you will probably feel the urge to return to it in the future. Also as you have probably read already the community can be garbage, but interestingly funny garbage.

reviewText: Considering how inherently cool medieval combat is, it’s a wonder that games based on knights and castles don’t rival zombies when it comes to first-person popularity. Thankfully those hankering for some heavily armoured king slaying now have a superb game that is just what the Knights Templar ordered.Chivalry: Medieval Warfare is a multiplayer-only, first/third-person, hack-and-slasher that grabs most full priced games by the throat, tells them they’re unfit to polish Chivalry’s armour, before running them through with three feet of tempered steel.Built on the Unreal engine, each of the huge levels makes the areas in most other online shooters look like lifeless miniature movie sets. These vast medieval playgrounds are filled with huge castles, wooded forests, and moonlit cliffs. They’re not mere static backdrops for the carnage within, as each area is brimming with life; catapults flinging boulders at crumbling defences; ships circling in the bay under incoming ballista fire; the crowd cheering on in the arena.Full limb dismemberment and decapitation reward particularly effective strikes, and your weapons and armour will be covered in blood by the end of a match. Both first and third-person options are available depending on your preference.Matching the visual brutality are some of the most gut-wrenching sound effects heard in gaming.It looks and sounds great, but how does Chivalry play? This is a game all about melee weapons, so how the hell do you translate that to mouse and keyboard control? Pretty damn well, apparently.Longbows and crossbows control just like a normal shooter, except they take a little while to ready up. Swords, maces and axes require an entirely different set of buttons. Right mouse button is used to block, left mouse is used as a standard horizontal slashing attack, mouse wheel down is a thrusting jab, while mouse wheel up is a powerful overhead blow.Sounds simple, right? It’s anything but. This game is frickin’ hard.Mastering the basics of combat is made even trickier by the four different classes, which all have different strengths.I really enjoyed my time with Chivalry: Medieval Warfare. It was a difficult game to begin with, but after some practice and finding a good team to play with, I couldn’t help but have a good time.

reviewText:
There is a list of reasons for my thumbs down below. All you need to know if you're looking to buy is this:

-This game is not for casual players OR new players. If you did not own this game a year or two ago, don't buy it now. You will be destroyed. You will lose. You will be angry. Save yourself the frustration.-




Let me start off by saying I have a great and many hours on this game. I started playing more than a year ago, when things were a lot more fun. As time went on, the enjoyment started to sink away. I beat a good part of the learning curve and began to shine more. I would have recommended this game, and did. I brought friends to play with. Sadly, in the end, key things broke my loyalty.

1: Community. The community of this game will make you hate all of humanity. They're (not all, but many) childish and insulting. Totally unhelpful. You will run into that guy" that kicks you over and over again on your own team to goad you into attacking him so he can votekick you for team damage.

2: The patching. I'm not going to sit here and say something about the ballance between classes with the patches. No. It is that each time they patch the game
date: more of it seems to break. Be it your weapon unlocks
hoursPlayed: or the whole screen going black while you play- Torn Banner is all out of free passes in my book to get this process right.\n\n3: Hacking. There are two types of people that will tell you this doesn't happen. 1 is the guy that defends this game and thinks you're just a noob. 2 is the hacker. I knew hackers in this game

reviewText: This game is solely multi-player based. There are only 4 classes to play and a wide variety of weapons to choose from. The physics in this game are amazing which also takes battling into account for. Trust me, when you get hit, you will feel it. And one on one battles do feel personal on the battlefield. My only gripes with this game is when you die in team matches, you only get 1 life until everybody on eihter team dies. This is the only way to respawn, otherwise you will be in specteter mode. There is also a few bugs here and there but nothing that will effect gameplay. With dedicated servers and enough people to play I recommend this game. I probably give this game a 7.5/10.

reviewText: I can't hide how much fun this game is! The combat is fast, visceral and deep. Much deeper than many people realize, and glance over it saying it pales in comparison to M&B or WotR. Combining the 3 basic slashes, combos, a directional parry, kicks, ducks and jumps, feints, footwork and coordination give even the most dedicated melee enthusiasts such a various move set at their disposal. Finding a weapon and class combination, whether you want to be a tower shield wielding Defender or an offensive, jumpy Man at Arms give loads of experimentation. The game modes range from simple Team Deathmatch and King of the Hill to a multi-tiered Team Objective mode taking place in beautiful maps, where teams will raid villages, push siege weapons, sink enemy ships, and (in my personal favorite segment) the player on the top of the leaderboard will become the King, and their team must defend him with their lives while the enemy charge in waves through the throne room. The immersion in the game is top notch, as your army lets the enemy hear their battlecries as they charge, blades clash together, you hear screaming from the distance, siege weapons wreck the battlefield and you truly feel the scope of your actions. I can recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun medieval game that, in my humble opinion, has the best melee system in any game to date.

reviewText:
Chivarly, on the face looks like a good game that is offering something that is unique. But sadly, no, just no.
Potential - the gamestyle is unique, but the execution of the game is poor.

The Problems:

1) Having 100+ ping will make the game impossible to play against people. You will be unable to block, whilst everyone will always block you.
2) Countless crashes, for some reason Medieval Warfare crashes whilst it's expansion does not. This is just poor development.
3) After buying the game, you will basically have to pay more money to get new gear.
4) Combat becomes a complete mess and a block-fest after a while in game.
5) After a hour of gameplay, I felt completely bored of the game.
6) A game that allows for tactical gameplay, does not have any tools or anything to help a team improve their tactical ability.
7) The game does not feel fun, it becomes a total grind

The Ups:

1) Graphics and gore is a huge plus, has great immersion to the game.

Conclusion:

Currently the game is on special for 6 dollars, I fear to buy it even if it's 75% off.

reviewText:
Chivalry is hands down the best medeival FPS on the market, other titles such as War of the Roses and mount and blade just dont compare. The gameplay is beutiful, fast paced and brutal completely dependant on skill rather than buying better weapons. The classes are well balanced, archer seems a bit slow when notching his bow but this gives it a sense of realism. The maps for the most part are epic. Dont waste time on arena matches, team objectives are where the actions at. Amazingly fun sieges with battering rams, catapults and balista make the team objective maps some of the best in the game. However, the best moment by far is when you assault the enemy keep and assasinate their king.

The game does have some glaring bugs, however these can be ignored for the most part.
The worst of these being weapon kills not counting, making it impossible to get new weapons, the kills will count occasionaly it will just take longer to level up.
There are also issues with hits not counting, blocking not working, however i have not experienced these yet in the several matches ive played. Might be caused by lag or slow internet.
Not really a bug but im going to put it here anyway: Teamkills, if your with a good group of players this shouldnt bother you to much, occasionaly getting hit by a friendly vangaurd whose spamming lmb. However if your not with a good group of players you will get the occasional (censored) on your team, who thinks it is funny to sneak up behind you while your fighting and stab you. Fortunately there is a nice ban system to get rid of these trolls.

Overalll this game is well worth the 8.50$ i spent on it after using a coupon. I would really like to see a healer or mage class though this probably wont be implemented, seeing as this game is medeival, not fantasy medeival.

To the king!

Edit: This is a review for the deadliest warrior expansion.

So far the game runs slower than chivalry, I had to turn all the graphics down.
The new classes are very fun to play, especialy samurai and pirate.
The maps are not anything exemplary. Most are too big for the amount of players and they are all arena style, no objective maps yet. I spend a lot of time looking for people to fight instead of fighting.
The new charachter progression system is nice, leveling up the charachters you play as rather than one profile as a whole.
The vanity system is also a nice feature to help stand out on the battlefield, and its free...currently.
Overall well worth the 5$ i payed during sale. The game could really use some better maps though. I would really like to see the normal chivalry maps ported over.
